bio: Mridula Baljekar is a Bangladeshi-born British chef and cookbook author. She has written numerous cookbooks, including the award-winning 'The Curry Lover's Cookbook' and 'The Complete Indian Cookbook'. Baljekar is known for her modern take on traditional Indian and Bangladeshi cuisine.

recipes.cooking_method: Cut the fish fillets into cubes. Finely chop the onion, tomato, and green chilies. Heat some oil in a large pan over medium-high heat. Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden brown. Add the tomato, green chilies, and cumin powder and cook for a few minutes. Add some water and bring to a boil. Add the fish fillets and simmer for 5-10 minutes or until the fish is cooked through. Serve with steamed rice.

Peel and dice the potatoes. Soak the poppy seeds in water for 30 minutes. Grind the poppy seeds and green chilies to a paste. Heat the mustard oil in a pan over medium heat. Add the diced potatoes and sauté until golden brown. Add the turmeric powder and poppy seed paste and cook for a few minutes. Add some water and simmer until the potatoes are cooked through. Serve with roti or paratha.

Finely chop the onion, tomatoes, and green chilies. Heat some oil in a pan over medium heat. Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden brown. Add the chopped tomatoes, green chilies, and garam masala and cook for a few minutes. Add the chickpeas and some water and simmer for 10-15 minutes or until the chickpeas are tender. Serve with steamed rice or naan.

bio: Shawkat Osman is a Bangladeshi chef and restaurateur. He is the founder of several popular restaurants in Bangladesh, including 'The Spice Room' and 'The Bistro'. Osman is known for his fusion cuisine, blending traditional Bangladeshi flavors with modern techniques and ingredients.

recipes.cooking_method: Cut the beef into small pieces. Finely chop the onion, tomato, and green chilies. Heat some oil in a large pan over medium-high heat. Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden brown. Add the tomato, green chilies, and ginger paste and cook for a few minutes. Add the beef and some water and simmer for 30-45 minutes or until the beef is tender. Serve with steamed rice or naan.

Soak the rice in water for 30 minutes. Cut the chicken into small pieces. Finely chop the onion and tomato. Heat some oil in a large pan over medium heat. Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden brown. Add the chopped tomato and garam masala and cook for a few minutes. Add the chicken and some water and simmer for 20-30 minutes or until the chicken is cooked through. Cook the rice in a separate pot according to package instructions. Layer the chicken and rice in a large baking dish. Cover and bake in the oven at 350°F for 20-30 minutes. Serve hot.

recipes.recipe_name: Palak Paneer (Spinach and Cottage Cheese Curry)
recipes.cooking_method: Blanch the spinach in boiling water for 1-2 minutes. Drain and finely chop. Cut the cottage cheese into small cubes. Finely chop the onion and tomato. Heat some oil in a pan over medium heat. Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden brown. Add the chopped tomato and cumin powder and cook for a few minutes. Add the chopped spinach and cottage cheese and simmer for 5-10 minutes or until the cottage cheese is heated through. Serve with steamed rice or naan.

bio: Tasneem Kabir is a Bangladeshi food blogger and cookbook author. She is known for her creative and easy-to-follow recipes that showcase the flavors of Bangladesh. Kabir's popular blog, 'Spice and Sugar Tales', has been featured in several international publications.

recipes.cooking_method: Peel and devein the shrimp. Finely chop the onion and tomato. Heat some oil in a pan over medium heat. Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden brown. Add the chopped tomato, cumin powder, and coriander powder and cook for a few minutes. Add the shrimp and some water and simmer for 5-10 minutes or until the shrimp is cooked through. Serve with steamed rice or naan.

Cut the fish into small pieces. Finely chop the onion, tomato, and green chilies. Heat some oil in a large pan over medium-high heat. Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden brown. Add the tomato, green chilies, turmeric powder, and some water and cook for a few minutes. Add the fish and some more water and simmer for 10-15 minutes or until the fish is cooked through. Serve with steamed rice.

Peel and chop the potatoes into small cubes. Soak the poppy seeds in water for 30 minutes. Finely chop the onion. Heat some oil in a pan over medium heat. Add the cumin seeds and sauté for a few seconds. Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden brown. Drain the poppy seeds and grind to a fine paste. Add the poppy seed paste, chopped potatoes, and some water to the pan. Simmer for 10-15 minutes or until the potatoes are cooked through. Serve with steamed rice.

bio: Nadia Rahman is a Bangladeshi chef who specializes in traditional Bengali cuisine. She is known for her unique twist on classic Bengali dishes, using local and seasonal ingredients to add flavor and depth. Rahman has been featured in several food magazines and has won numerous awards for her innovative dishes.

recipes.cooking_method: Cut the chicken into small pieces. Finely chop the onion and tomatoes. Crush the garlic cloves. Heat some oil in a pan over medium heat. Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden brown. Add the crushed garlic and ginger paste and sauté for a few seconds. Add the chopped tomatoes and cook for a few minutes. Add the chicken and some water and simmer for 10-15 minutes or until the chicken is cooked through. Serve with steamed rice.

Cut the Hilsa fish into medium sized pieces. Finely chop the onion. In a mixing bowl, mix the fish pieces with onion, turmeric powder, red chili powder, salt, and mustard oil. In a steamer, steam the fish mixture for 10-15 minutes or until the fish is cooked through. Serve hot with steamed rice.

Peel and devein the prawns. Finely chop the onion. Heat some oil in a pan over medium heat. Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden brown. Add the turmeric powder and red chili powder and sauté for a few seconds. Add the prawns and some water and cook for a few minutes. Add the coconut milk and simmer for 10-15 minutes or until the prawns are cooked through. Serve with steamed rice.

bio: Rahim Ahmed is a Bangladeshi chef with a passion for fusion cuisine. His innovative dishes blend traditional Bangladeshi flavors with global ingredients and techniques, creating a unique culinary experience. Ahmed has worked in several high-end restaurants in Bangladesh and has won numerous awards for his creative dishes.

recipes.cooking_method: Peel and devein the shrimp. Cut the onion, bell pepper, and carrot into thin slices. Heat some oil in a pan over high heat. Add the shrimp and stir-fry until cooked through. Remove from the pan and set aside. Add some more oil to the pan and add the sliced onion, bell pepper, and carrot. Stir-fry until the vegetables are cooked through. Add the cooked shrimp back to the pan and drizzle with soy sauce. Serve with steamed rice.

Mix the ground beef with chopped onion, garlic, garam masala, and salt. Shape into small balls. Heat some oil in a pan over medium heat. Add the meatballs and fry until browned on all sides. Remove from the pan and set aside. In the same pan, add chopped onion and sauté until golden brown. Add chopped tomatoes and cook for a few minutes. Add the meatballs back to the pan and add some water. Simmer for 10-15 minutes or until the meatballs are cooked through. Serve with naan or rice.

Drain and rinse the chickpeas. Finely chop the onion and tomatoes. Crush the garlic cloves. Heat some oil in a pan over medium heat. Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden brown. Add the crushed garlic and cumin powder and sauté for a few seconds. Add the chopped tomatoes and cook for a few minutes. Add the chickpeas and some water and simmer for 10-15 minutes or until the chickpeas are heated through. Serve with naan or rice.

bio: Mehnaz Akter is a Bangladeshi chef with a focus on healthy and flavorful dishes. She believes in using fresh, locally-sourced ingredients and creating dishes that are both nutritious and delicious. Akter has worked in several restaurants in Bangladesh and has also done catering for private events and parties.

recipes.cooking_method: Peel and dice the sweet potatoes into small cubes. Slice the red onion into thin slices. Drain and rinse the chickpeas. Preheat the oven to 400°F. Toss the sweet potatoes and red onion with olive oil and spread on a baking sheet. Roast for 20-25 minutes or until the sweet potatoes are tender and slightly crispy. Let cool for a few minutes. Toss with chickpeas and chopped parsley. Serve warm or at room temperature.

Cut the chicken thighs into bite-sized pieces. Finely chop the onion and tomatoes. Crush the garlic cloves. Heat some oil in a pan over medium heat. Add the chopped onion and sauté until golden brown. Add the crushed garlic and curry powder and sauté for a few seconds. Add the chopped tomatoes and cook for a few minutes. Add the chicken pieces and some water and simmer for 20-25 minutes or until the chicken is cooked through. Serve with rice or naan.

Heat some oil in a pan over high heat. Add the chopped broccoli, sliced carrots, sliced bell peppers, and sliced mushrooms. Stir-fry for a few minutes until the vegetables are tender but still slightly crisp. Drizzle with soy sauce and stir to coat. Serve with rice or noodles.
